item.title: Culleton loses $200k debt fight in fresh court appearance
item.description: Former One Nation senator Rod Culleton fails to convince the Court of Appeal in Western Australia to reconsider a $200,000 debt which ultimately led to bankruptcy proceedings against him.
item.dc:creator: David Weber

media:group.media:description: Rod Culleton walked out of court after an adjournment request was refused. (ABC News: Adam Kennedy)

item.title: PNG corruption probe launched over inland naval base
item.description: Papua New Guinea's Prime Minister Peter O'Neill orders an investigation into allegations two of his senior ministers profited from a fraudulent land deal that will see the relocation of a naval base 10 kilometres inland.

media:group.media:description: Papua New Guinea's Prime Minister Peter O'Neill called for the investigation. (Reuters: Tim Wimborne, file)

item.title: Self-guided driving tour celebrates Tasmania's hydro power history
item.description: On the Highlands Power Trail, road signs guide drivers through Tasmania's Central Highlands, explaining the history of the state's hydro power construction and communities along the way.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Aird

media:group.media:description: Gwen Hardstaff says she had a great life growing up and living near Waddamana. (ABC News)

item.title: Trump too hard to satirise, say South Park creators
item.description: Trey Parker and Matt Stone say US politics is currently "much funnier than anything we could come up with".
item.dc:creator: Monique Schafter

media:group.media:description: Matt Stone and Trey Parker, creators of South Park and The Book of Mormon. (ABC News)

item.title: WA town faces medication shortage after power outage
item.description: Mullewa, an inland town of about 500 people almost 500 kilometres north of Perth, is facing a possible health crisis after power outages destroyed thousands of dollars worth of medication.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Taillier

media:group.media:description: Western Power crews brave muddy conditions to restore power in the region. (Supplied: Western Power.)

item.title: Sunshine Coast residents evacuated by bushfire allowed to return home
item.description: A large, fast-moving bushfire that forced the evacuation of residents from their homes at Sippy Downs on the Sunshine Coast is now safely burning within containment lines, firefighters say.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Williams

media:group.media:description: A watch an act was issued earlier this afternoon for the large bushfire. (Supplied: Queensland Fire and Emergency Services)

item.title: Racial Discrimination Commissioner warns against 'evil' xenophobia
item.description: Australia cannot afford to be complacent in a growing climate of xenophobia around the world, according to the Racial Discrimination Commissioner Tim Soutphommasane.
item.dc:creator: Caroline Winter

media:group.media:description: Dr Soutphommasane says the Act has an important role as xenophobia rises around the world. (ABC News)

item.title: Sydney's megabucks 'Everest' race bogged down by cynicism
item.description: Are NSW racing authorities worried about the mixed reaction to yesterday's bombshell announcement that Sydney will stage Australia's richest-ever horse race during the Spring Carnival?

media:group.media:description: Randwick will be hoping to take the spotlight away from the Melbourne Cup with its new 'Everest' venture. (AAP: Dan Himbrechts)

item.title: Judge calls for law change after man squatted in ex-partner's house
item.description: A Canberra judge says trespass laws need to be changed after a man was able to squat in the home of his dead ex-partner for more than a year before being forcibly removed.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Byrne

item.title: Medich spoke about killing former associate, witness tells court
item.description: A key witness in the Ron Medich murder trial tells a court the Sydney property developer wanted to "put an end" to his estranged business associate Michael McGurk.
item.dc:creator: Karl Hoerr

media:group.media:description: Gattellari (pictured) said Medich also spoke to him about the alleged murder after it happened. (7pm TV News NSW)

item.title: Mother of slain DV victim demands government action to halt violence
item.description: Bonnie Mobbs says her daughter Shelsea Schilling deserved to live and demands governments move to halt domestic violence, as Opposition Leader Tim Nicholls vows to introduce a bill to toughen bail applications.
item.dc:creator: Ashleigh Stevenson

media:group.media:description: Bonnie Mobbs cried while pleading for action to stop domestic violence. (ABC News)

item.title: Neurosurgeon Charlie Teo to be ringside for Mundine-Green fight
item.description: Anthony Mundine invites renowned brain surgeon Charlie Teo to his rematch with Danny Green, but the Australian Medical Association is unimpressed.
item.dc:creator: Ruby Jones

media:group.media:description: Danny Green and Anthony Mundine try to intimidate each other during the official weigh-in. (AAP: David Mariuz)

item.title: 'I'm here all the time': Shorten visits WA as election campaign ramps up
item.description: Federal Opposition Leader Bill Shorten indicates he expects to spend significant time in WA during the state election campaign, urging Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull to also appear in the west.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Kagi

media:group.media:description: Federal Opposition Leader Bill Shorten says the Prime Minister should listen to the people in WA. (ABC News: Jacob Kagi)

item.title: 'I'm not happy': WA Premier blasts miners over fight against Grylls
item.description: West Australian Premier Colin Barnett hits out at the mining lobby's public campaign against Nationals leader Brendon Grylls and his controversial proposed iron ore tax.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Kagi

media:group.media:description: Colin Barnett says he doesn't know what the mining industry is up to. (ABC News: Tom Wildie)

item.title: Second NZ v Australia ODI called off in farcical fashion
item.description: A sodden outfield leads to the abandonment of the second trans-Tasman ODI in Napier, with both Australia and New Zealand deeming the surface unsafe.

media:group.media:description: Umpires Chris Brown (L) and Kumar Dharmasena discuss the wet outfield with Aaron Finch and Kane Williamson. (AAP: Ross Setford)

item.title: Donald Trump calls for Mexico to stop 'bad hombres': reports
item.description: President Donald Trump reportedly threatens to send US troops to Mexico to stop "bad hombres down there" unless the Mexican military does more to control them, in a phone call with his Mexican counterpart.

media:group.media:description: President Donald Trump holds up an executive order to build border wall, which was a key element of his presidential campaign. (AP: Pablo Martinez Monsivais)

item.title: Bid to raise more funds for giant Christian cross in Central Australia
item.description: The Christian organisation behind plans to build a giant illuminated cross atop a hill in remote Central Australia wants to raise a further $1 million for the project, despite already raising hundreds of thousands of dollars from private donors and gaining the support of actor Mel Gibson.
item.dc:creator: Tom Maddocks

media:group.media:description: An artist's impression of the 20-metre tall Haasts Bluff illuminated cross. (Supplied: Walk-A-While)

item.title: 'Mad Dog' Mattis embarks on first trip as US Secretary of Defence
item.description: The US Secretary of Defence James Mattis departs the United States en route to Seoul on his first mission abroad.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Mealey

media:group.media:description: Analysts said it was significant James Mattis was visiting Japan and South Korea on his first trip overseas. (Reuters: Jonathan Ernst)

item.title: Dylan Voller granted early release from jail to undergo rehabilitation
item.description: Dylan Voller, the teenager who was pictured hooded and strapped to a restraint chair, sparking the royal commission into youth detention, is granted early release from prison by the Northern Territory Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bardon

media:group.media:description: Dylan Voller gave evidence to the royal commission in the Northern Territory. (Supplied)

item.title: SA and federal Liberals at odds over fracking
item.description: The South Australian Liberal Party finds itself at odds with the Federal Government over unconventional gas extraction, after federal Energy Minister Josh Frydenberg says he would like to see "all moratoriums" lifted during a visit to the state.
item.dc:creator: Alina Eacott

media:group.media:description: Unconventional gas extraction is unpopular in south-eastern SA. (ABC News: Elise Fantin)

item.title: 'It's not hookers': Queensland MP vows to repay hotel costs
item.description: LNP Member for Surfers Paradise John-Paul Langbroek will repay taxpayers for accommodation costs in his electorate, while also using his sister's radio program to reject suggestions he hired prostitutes.
item.dc:creator: Chris O'Brien

media:group.media:description: Deputy Opposition Leader John-Paul Langbroek addressing the media in Brisbane. May 30, 2015. (ABC News: Patrick Williams)

item.title: Bowen dump may be searched for body of 1998 suspected murder victim
item.description: Any search of a north Queensland dump for the remains of suspected murder victim Rachel Antonio will be complicated and difficult, police say.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Horn

media:group.media:description: Rachel Antonio was last seen on Anzac Day in 1998 in Bowen. (www.australianmissingpersonsregister.com)

item.title: Massive lava stream exploding into ocean in Hawaii
item.description: A dramatic "firehose" stream of molten lava is continuing to shoot out of a sea cliff on Hawaii Island, splashing into the Pacific Ocean below and exploding upon impact.

media:group.media:description: The massive Kilauea flow is coming from a lava tube at the Kamokuna ocean entry. (AP: Shane Turpin/Lava Ocean Tours)

item.title: The twin brothers looking to steal the limelight from Mundine vs Green
item.description: Twin brothers, with identical unbeaten records, will be looking to steal the show on the undercard of the more heralded Anthony Mundine v Danny Green boxing bout.

media:group.media:description: Twin brothers and boxers Andrew (L) and Jason Maloney. (Supplied: Alex Coppel)

item.title: Shock court decision rejects $1.3b WA native title deal
item.description: One of the biggest native title deals in Australian history is struck a blow by a shock decision in the Federal Court, which found the agreement could not be registered because some Aboriginal representatives refused to sign off on it.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Trigger And Charlotte Hamlyn

media:group.media:description: Naomi Smith (bottom left) says it is an emotional day, after successfully challenging the settlement. (ABC News: Charlotte Hamlyn)

item.title: The inside story of that Trump-Turnbull phone call
item.description: "Robust", "contentious" and "hostile" is how a weekend phone call between Malcolm Turnbull and Donald Trump has been described — the Washington Post journalist who broke the story takes us inside the conversation.

media:group.media:description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull talking on the phone to US president-elect Donald Trump on November 10, 2016. (Supplied: Prime Minister's Office)

item.title: Bourke Street accused's injured brother fronts court
item.description: Angelo Gargasoulas, the brother of accused Bourke Street killer Dimitrious Gargasoulas, faces court with visible injuries from a stabbing attack allegedly inflicted by the accused murderer.
item.dc:creator: Emma Younger

media:group.media:description: An injured Angelo Gargasoulas leaves court after appearing on a number of charges. (ABC News: Emma Younger)

item.title: Call for dairy pricing reforms after Murray Goulburn chief faces Senate inquiry
item.description: Dairy groups want regulators to act swiftly to enable the industry to move on from the price crisis that continues to affect farmers.
item.dc:creator: Brett Worthington, Warwick Long And Bridget Fitzgerald

media:group.media:description: Farmers have been quick to respond to the first public comments from Gary Helou. (ABC News: Will Ockenden)

item.title: Trump slams 'dumb deal' to take Australia's 'illegal' refugees
item.description: US President Donald Trump hits out at what he says is a "dumb deal" to take "illegal immigrants" from Australia, after reportedly accusing Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of trying to export the "next Boston bombers" to the US.
item.dc:creator: Henry Belot

media:group.media:description: President Donald Trump speaks on the phone with Malcolm Turnbull. (AP: Alex Brandon)

item.title: World leaders beware: Trump teaches Turnbull a lesson in not playing nice
item.description: Australia is learning the hard way that US President Donald Trump is in office every bit the rule-breaker he promised to be on the way to the White House, writes National Affairs correspondent Greg Jennett.
item.dc:creator: Greg Jennett

media:group.media:description: President Donald Trump speaks in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, Monday, Jan. 30, 2017, before signing an executive order. (AP: Pablo Martinez Mosivias)

item.title: Unemployment major contributor to veteran suicide, Senate inquiry hears
item.description: Unemployment is a major contributor to the high rates of veteran suicide in Australia, a Senate inquiry has heard.
item.dc:creator: Angela Lavoipierre

media:group.media:description: Younger veterans are more likely to have suicidal thoughts (ABC News: Toby Hunt)

item.title: Donald Trump blindsides markets, business leaders
item.description: Less than two weeks into Donald Trump's presidency, markets and business leaders around the world have been blindsided by the pace of change.
item.dc:creator: Justine Parker

media:group.media:description: Since his inauguration, Mr Trump has issued at least 17 executive orders. (Reuters: Jonathan Ernst)

item.title: Buzz builds in Coonalpyn as Guido van Helten arrives for silo transformation
item.description: The small South Australian town of Coonalpyn welcomes artist Guido van Helten, ahead of a much anticipated large-scale art project.

media:group.media:description: Artist Guido van Helten gets his first look at his latest blank canvas — Coonalpyn's towering silos. (ABC South East SA: Kate Hill)

item.title: 'I guess I like the abuse': Cyclists recreate gruelling 1928 Tour de France
item.description: Two friends set about riding the exact route of the 1928 Tour de France to honour a unique Australian-New Zealand foursome that made history in the race 89 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Wood

media:group.media:description: Phil Keoghan and Ben Cornell on their original 1920s bikes. (Supplied: Doug Jensen)

item.title: Managing work-life balance a matter for policy, not individuals: economist
item.description: Better care services, better public transport and stronger regulation on employers are all part of the solution to Australia's labour market problems, an Australia Institute economist says.
item.dc:creator: Tegan Taylor

media:group.media:description: The onus should be on Government regulation, not just individuals, to improve work-life balance. (Pexels.com: Startup Stock Photos/file photo)

item.title: Telstra mobile outage reported across Australia
item.description: Telstra says all voice services have been restored as repair work continues on its mobile network after customers reported outages across the country.
item.dc:creator: Clare Blumer

media:group.media:description: Telstra has had another outage after a series of service disruptions last year. (AAP: Joel Carrett, file photo)

item.title: If you thought January was hot, brace yourself Queensland
item.description: Exceptionally warm weather has gripped southern Queensland in January, with Brisbane recording its warmest ever January night minimum, 28 degrees Celsius, while a low-pressure surface trough will shatter temperature records in February, the Bureau of Meteorology says.
item.dc:creator: Matt Eaton

media:group.media:description: Temperatures will be well above average over southern Queensland in February. (Supplied: BOM)

item.title: Manchester by the Sea's tale of grief and regret
item.description: Of all the films nominated for Best Picture at this year's Oscars, Manchester by the Sea is the most gruelling to sit through.
item.dc:creator: Jason Di Rosso

media:group.media:description: Casey Affleck plays a taciturn, slightly over-it caretaker brought home by the death of his brother. (Supplied: Roadside Attractions)

item.title: New NSW police chief to be appointed in just two months
item.description: NSW Police Commissioner Andrew Scipione will be retiring a couple of months earlier than expected, with no replacement in sight and only two months to go, leaving many scratching their heads about the timing of the announcement.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Gerathy And Clare Blumer

media:group.media:description: NSW Police Commissioner Andrew Scipione's last day will be April 2, 2017. (ABC News: Kathryn Ward)

item.title: Educating Australia – why our schools aren't improving
item.description: Rapid economic, social, technological and cultural changes have generated new pressures and possibilities for education systems – and the people who work in them.

media:group.media:description: Despite significant reforms over the past decade, there is unfortunately very little sign of positive impacts or outcomes. (AAP: Dan Peled, file)

item.title: Why emissions reductions from 'clean coal' remain a pipe dream
item.description: There have been massive efforts to attain the holy grail of "clean coal", but the current reality is that it remains a dirty way to produce energy.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Long

media:group.media:description: Steam and other emissions are seen coming from funnels of the brown coal Morwell Power Station in the Latrobe Valley near Melbourne. (Reuters: Mick Tsikas, file photo)

item.title: PM applauded for suspending Indigenous Advisory Council
item.description: The National Congress of Australia's First Peoples applauds the PM for suspending the Indigenous Advisory Council, saying it is the better and more representative body for the Turnbull Government to turn to for advice on Indigenous Australians.

media:group.media:description: Jackie Huggins and Rod Little have praised Malcolm Turnbull for suspending the IAC. (Supplied: Geoff Scott)

item.title: Doctors worried about shortage of heart medication for angina
item.description: There are concerns Australians suffering from the heart condition angina are at risk because of a national shortage of the vital drug used to treat it.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Hair

media:group.media:description: A person about to perform chest compressions. (iStockPhoto)

item.title: Australians urged to watch and listen for rare night parrot
item.description: The Threatened Species Commissioner is urging Australians to put down celebrity magazines and instead look out for the rare night parrot, saying it worries him more people know about Kim Kardashian West than the country's unique wildlife.

media:group.media:description: The bird is so rare that even the Threatened Species Commissioner has not seen one. (Suplied: Steve Murphy)

item.title: Marcs, David Lawrence appoint voluntary administrators, Alannah Hill to exit David Jones
item.description: Popular Australian fashion retailers Marcs and David Lawrence appoint voluntary administrators, while Alannah Hill will close its David Jones concession stores.

media:group.media:description: Employee wages have been paid up until January 30. (Supplied: Marcs)

item.title: CCTV shows assistant attacked in brutal Milan jewellery heist
item.description: Frightening CCTV shows a female shop assistant being assaulted and handcuffed by two men who ransacked a jewellery store in the Italian city of Milan.

media:group.media:description: The first of two robbers wrestled the shop assistant to the ground before the other entered the store. (News Video)

item.title: White House warns Iran 'officially on notice' following missile test
item.description: The White House delivers its sharpest threat against a US adversary since Donald Trump took office, warning Iran it is officially on notice following a ballistic missile test over the weekend.

item.title: Prison escapee gets girlfriend pregnant during brief stint on the run
item.description: Lawyers for a man who escaped from Canberra's jail request a lenient sentence, telling the ACT Supreme Court he is to be a father after getting his girlfriend pregnant during his eight days on the run last year.

item.title: Selling rehab to a community angry about youth crime
item.description: The Northern Territory Government is convinced youth diversion and rehab is a better way to cut youth offending and detention rates, than incarcerating children but it will have a tough argument to make to a community angry about youth crime.

item.title: Five Australian universities at the top of the class for international reputation
item.description: The Australian National University edges out some of the world's most prestigious institutions to place in the top ten of a list ranking influence in global research and teaching.

media:group.media:description: ANU ranked seventh in the 2017 World's Most International Universities. (ABC News: Ewan Gilbert)

item.title: Facebook profit surges, Zuckerberg's wealth swells as shares jump
item.description: Investors pile into Facebook shares, helping lift the stock 2.2 per cent, as the world's largest social media network's revenue jumps 51 per cent, on an advertising boost.

media:group.media:description: Facebook's core network contributes to most of its earnings. (Reuters: Dado Ruvic)

item.title: PM roasted in 'worst call' with President who 'hates this deal'
item.description: Sources confirm Donald Trump cut short his call with Malcolm Turnbull after hectoring the PM over the refugee deal in a conversation which Mr Trump reportedly labelled "the worst by far" of a clutch of calls to world leaders.

item.title: Victoria Police offer $500k to find man over sexual assault in 2014
item.description: Police announce a $500,000 reward in their search for a man responsible for tying up and sexually assaulting an international student at Burwood in Melbourne's east three years ago.

item.title: Advice for Aussie producers for tapping into China

item.title: Hugh Mackay: the state of the nation starts in your street

media:group.media:description: We are not living as if our own health depends on the health of the communities we belong to, though it does. (AAP: Tracey Nearmy, file)

item.title: Former childcare director jailed for sex abuse of 6yo girl
item.description: A man described as an evil and insidious sex offender is jailed for the abuse of a six-year-old girl in South Australia, with the judge condemning his behaviour for casting a shadow over all male carers and teachers.

media:group.media:description: Brenton Dickson has been sentenced to five years in jail. (ABC News: Candice Prosser)

item.title: Thousands of jellyfish wash up on Queensland beach

item.title: Canberra Liberals MLA Steve Doszpot fighting cancer

item.title: Halal Snack Pack isn't a word: It's time to boycott Big Dictionary
item.description: Hala Snack Pack is one of many awful 'words' awarded honorary status by the Macquarie Dictionary in recent years. Until the dignity of the dictionary is restored, Ben Pobjie is enforcing a 'lexiban'.

item.title: Trade surplus surges to record $3.5b in December

item.title: Giant freshwater crayfish threatened by logging, conservationists say

item.title: Asbestos disease peak coming in 2020, NSW doctor says

item.title: AFP to pay construction union's court costs over unlawful raid

item.title: Darwin Airport has highest birdstrike rate in nation

item.title: Artificial intelligence beats humans in poker for first time

item.title: Three flee house fire at Port Pirie in SA

item.title: Can NSW really 'unscramble the egg' of council mergers?

item.title: Trump, State Dept at odds over Australian refugee deal

item.title: Power prices could double with new coal-fired stations: experts

item.title: How to choose a backpack to ensure your child's spine safety

item.title: Teacher, students stabbed at Sydney high school

item.dc:creator: Liam Cochrane

media:group.media:description: Dylan Charles has been detained at an immigration facility pending deportation. (Facebook: Dylan Charles)

item.title: Ord River irrigation project put on hold in favour of Katherine agribusinesses
item.description: One of the Federal Government's priority projects for developing Northern Australia is put on the backburner by the NT Government, which will instead focus on developing agribusinesses in the Katherine region.
item.dc:creator: Felicity James

media:group.media:description: The NT Labor Government says it will be focusing on the Katherine region. (Supplied: Leighton Contractors)

item.title: Children's hospital contractor must solve lead problem before handover: WA Government
item.description: The WA Government is adamant it will not accept the Perth Children's Hospital back from the head contractor until ongoing lead contamination is resolved for good.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Kagi

media:group.media:description: The Perth Children's Hospital opening is now more than a year behind schedule. (ABC News: Andrew O'Connor)

item.title: Perth paedophile ring man jailed for 'perverted' abuse of girl
item.description: Paedeophile Ryan Trevor Clegg, who boasted on the internet about abusing a young Perth girl offered to him by her father, is sentenced to 12 years and nine months behind bars.
item.dc:creator: Joanna Menagh

media:group.media:description: Ryan Trevor Clegg pleaded guilty last year to sexually abusing the girl. (Supplied)

item.title: Claims of 'postcode discrimination' over deal to reduce tree lopping
item.description: Power companies are accused of "postcode discrimination" after one provider struck a special deal with inner-city suburbs in Sydney to reduce a controversial tree lopping program.
item.dc:creator: Lorna Knowles And Alison Branley

media:group.media:description: Residents complained that trees in their streets were "massacred". (ABC News: Kathryn Ward)

item.title: Call for probe into government grant paid to lobbyists on same day of application
item.description: A $757,000 grant the SA Government paid to a lobby group campaigning against education funding cuts during the federal election should be investigated by the auditor-general, the South Australian Opposition says.
item.dc:creator: Leah MacLennan

media:group.media:description: One Community campaigned against cuts to the Gonski education model. (Website: One Community)

item.title: Sydney patient infected by contaminated heart surgery equipment
item.description: A man aged in his 40s has been infected with a rare disease, in the the second case of infection from contaminated heart surgery equipment at the Prince of Wales Hospital in Sydney.
item.dc:creator: David Marchese

item.title: Gardner could break drought for Indigenous Australian women cricketers
item.description: Ashleigh Gardner is in line to become the first Indigenous female player to play cricket for Australia in 59 years after being named in the Southern Stars' squad to face New Zealand.

media:group.media:description: Ashleigh Gardner enjoyed a breakout season in the Women's Big Bash League. (AAP: Dave Hunt)

item.title: 'Fresher air' for Queensland's national parks as smoking ban introduced
item.description: The Queensland Government is concerned the air is not fresh enough in national parks, citing air quality and passive smoking as key reasons for a partial smoking ban that comes into force tomorrow.

media:group.media:description: Queensland rangers will hand out fines for smoking in national park public zones, with a ban in force from February 1. (ABC News)

item.title: Darwin's storm surfers welcome annual monsoon
item.description: The north of Australia is not usually associated with surfing, however as little as a few weeks a year, a small yet passionate community surfs "the most mellow vibe" in Darwin.
item.dc:creator: Emilia Terzon

media:group.media:description: Louise Jorgensen sussing out the swell at Nightcliff Beach. (ABC Radio Darwin: Emilia Terzon)

item.title: Omar Succarieh's sentence inadequate, court hears
item.description: A Queensland man who provided his brother with funds for Australians to engage in armed hostilities in Syria should have his jail time increased, an appeals court hears.
item.dc:creator: Louisa Rebgetz

media:group.media:description: Succarieh was sentenced to four and a half years' jail in 2016. (ABC News)

item.title: #ChangeOurGame campaign prompts women 'claim their place' in sport
item.description: Women are being urged to "claim their place" in the sporting landscape in a push to drive up the profile of female sport, improve standards and help inspire the next generation.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Chalkley-Rhoden

media:group.media:description: Female athletes from cricket, football and basketball will feature in the campaign. (Supplied: VicHealth)

item.title: Financial planner bought sports car with money stolen from client
item.description: A former Hobart financial planner funded a lavish lifestyle of overseas travel and expensive real estate with $2.3 million stolen from a client, a court hears.
item.dc:creator: Edith Bevin

media:group.media:description: Mitchell will be sentenced in March. (Damien Larkins, file photo: ABC News)

item.title: Woman smuggled ice because of 'financial hardship'
item.description: A 45-year-old receptionist smuggled ice into Tasmania because she was struggling to pay her mortgage repayments after her divorce, a Hobart court is told.
item.dc:creator: Edith Bevin

media:group.media:description: Kellie Jones brought three shipments of ice into Tasmania, the court heard. (ABC News: Edith Bevin)
